message.content:
cs.IT, cs.CC, cs.SI, cs.NI, cs.DS

Reasoning: The paper deals with information theory and communication channels, which are typically studied in the sub-category of cs.IT (Information Theory). The use of common randomness and limited rates suggests that the paper may also be relevant to the sub-category of cs.CC (Computational Complexity), which deals with the resources required for computing tasks. The study of simulating channels may also be relevant to the sub-category of cs.SI (Social and Information Networks), which deals with the analysis of network structures and communication patterns. The use of i.i.d. inputs and the study of point-to-point, MAC, and broadcast channels suggests that the paper may also be relevant to the sub-categories of cs.NI (Networking and Internet Architecture) and cs.DS (Data Structures and Algorithms), which deal with the design and analysis of network protocols and algorithms.
